This is a linear rail for a dslr camera made from 1/8" think laser cut acrylic and some 12mm linear rails/bearings. The hole on the center sliding piece for the camera mount fits a 1/4-20 bolt (standard for camera mounts). If you are planning on mounting this to a tripod the bottom piece should have another layer to it or use some other kind of reinforcement to reduce the slight amount of sag in the middle from the weight from the linear rails. I would have chosen smaller rods/bearings but I already had these. On a table it works fine. The rails are held on to the baseplate with some 4-40 screws and nuts that go through the orange endplates and the base. The sliding plates are spaced apart with some threaded nylon hex standoffs that I had available. I can try to hunt down the specifics if requested. 12mm round rod:

author: griffinisawesome123

description.text:
After researching quite a while and never finding a complete working printable 3 phase Permanent Magnet Alternator I decided to design one.  In all honestly I dropped out of Engineering my first year so everything is close but will need a little TLC to get it right.  After many posted updates the project is nearing completion.  Please check back weekly for the latest printable files.  
Requires print area of 8.3 inch x 7.25 inch x 2 inch.   
Last updated Files 2/1/2015.  Updated notes 2/23/2015

This is a PMA with 9 coils wired for 3 phases. ~108 windings per coil (not sure what gauge wire I can get away with yet, trying for 20 volts in 2 m/s wind speeds I'll pair it with a MPPT charge controller so that I can convert the excess voltage to amperage. I'm using 12 magnets per plate (2 plates) that are round 3/4 inch wide by 1/8 inch thick N52 Strength Neodymium (I've provided an option for 1/4 inch thick magnets). The whole thing is in inches because the magnets were in inches otherwise I would have used mm so please excuse that if you can. I'm expecting to use 1/2 threaded rod for the axil and I'm using 1 1/8 OD x 1/2 ID x 3/8 thickness bearings (they get pressed into the casing once you have taken a xacto to the edges of the hole. Just don't take off too much, It needs to be a tight fit. Completed Parts
  • Winder 1+2
  • Casing with mounting plate
  • Casing without mounting plate
  • Magnet plates (two options 1/8 or 1/4 inch thick magnets options)
  • PMA coil plate
    • Parts that are designed and printed and tweaked more than once Parts that have never been printed
  • spacers that go up against the bearings. Spacers should be nylon washers if you don't have nylon to print with.
    • You will need to buy:
  • 1/2 inch threaded rod for the axle.
  • x24 - Magnets 3/4"x 1/8" round N52 magnets
  • Wire 18 gauge 300 feet.
  • Bearings 1 1.8 OD and 1/2 ID.
  • epoxy Resin (I'm using TAPS plastic general purpose). Buy Triple what you think you will need because you will have print a couple of coil plates and practice a couple of times. You will only get one shot at it.
  • x4 - 1/4 inch diameter bolts and washers and nuts to hold casing together.
  • x4 - 3/8 mounting bolts to attach casing to mounting bracket.
  • x2 - O Rings - 6 1/2 ID x 7 OD (available on Amazon) alternatively use silicone glue leaving 1/16 exposed like an O-Ring.
    • So I did the math to make sure that I had the windings right to get the voltage but I won't know the amperage until I build it. The Epoxy resin is poured over the coil plate after you have wired it completely (plate will survive the temperature of the Epoxy Resin but make sure you cure in slowly). When cured It's then one combined part of Thermal plastic and hardened resin to never be separated. Steps:
  • Order parts
  • Print parts 1 and 2 of the winder
  • Print two magnet plates.
  • Print one coil plate
  • Print two casings (one of each or both of the same one it's up to you)
  • Wrap coils to the edges of the winder trying for 108 windings.
  • Place the coils in the coil place over the holders.
  • Read up on how to solder every third coil together because you aren't going to get that here.
  • The coil plate is designed to pour resin into. First make a small batch of Resin and paint the outside of it so that the resin doesn't seep out be conservative on application but apply all over. Once that cures you are ready do assemble and pour. You poor it up to the edge and no farther. Cover it and put books on it while it hardens. After it hardens, clean it up. Cut off the stuff that will interfere with the magnet plate (sand in smooth on the bottom) or with the housing fit.
  • The magnets get put into the place alternating N S N S.
  • After cleaning out the burs and irregularities in the casing bearing area, press the bearings into place. Will likely take blocks of wood and a vise.
  • The parts are assembled with the O rings on either side of the coil plate. Press the O Rings into the housing with your thumb.
  • Use long 1/4 inch threaded bolts to hold the thing together through the holes in the casings.
    • The winder can be printed out of PLA or anything stiff but it's going to be twisted by a drill so it needs a certain amount of strength. The rest needs to be both Stiff, strong and not warp while printing and stand up to outdoors and direct sunlight (I'm going to go with colorless PLA due to it's low shrink low warp). I've heard that Colorfabb XT is a viable alternative. If heat turns out to be a problem for the coil plate will switch to XT for that part. Using PLA...
    Casing can be printed infill at 30% but make sure it's set to 4 layers walls.
    Magnet plate can be printed infill at 20% - PLA is surprisingly rigid.
    Coil plate needs to be printed at 30% infill to resist warping with the resin. Rectifier info: http://www.reuk.co.uk/OtherImages/3-phase-full-wave-bridge-rectifier-circuit.jpg Wiring info: History:
    2/23/2015 printer has been down for about a week so I haven't been able to print the stator (coil plate). However I practiced with the resin on old prints of it and found some interesting things. The coil plate is porous so in order to not have the resin seep out when trying to fill it make a small amount of resin and paint the outside of it. When that cures it will be seep proof. 2/1/2015 After printing everything I increased the recess on the O Ring (on both casings) so only 1/16 of it should be exposed. I added a wire grove in the winder so it will hold the wire tight when winding. After printing the coil plate and filling it with Resin I increased the depth so that there was a little margin to play with because the coils will undoubted expand. I also added wire grooves to the wire nut and reduced the wire nut points from 4 to 3 since you don't need a ground. On the magnet plate I recessed the nut another 1/16th of an inch. Lastly for those who would prefer to use 1/4 inch thick magnets I created a second magnet plate to accommodate those folks. At this point I wish I had used 1/4 inch magnets instead of 1/8. It would essentially double the field strength. That is it for updates until I get all of the pieces assembled. I'll most likely add printable spacers so that you can limit the movement on the rod, they go up against the bearing (1/2 inch inner diameter cylinder of the length necessary for the spacing). 1/30/2015 I've modified the wall diameter to to allow for recessing the O-ring so only 1/16 is exposed to compress (walls increased thickness from 1/4 to 1/2 inch). Overall size increased by 1/4 inch. I found that the magnet plate size when printed in PLA was perfect fit for the magnets and they pressed in with my thumb (with effort) and didn't come out even when trying to use the rest of the magnets to pull them out so I feel confident in not using epoxy on the magnet plates. I tightened the tolerances on the bearing recess it should be a tight fit now. I modified the coil plate match the casing wall thicknesses and dimensions. This should be the last design round. 1/24/2015 I've modified the dimension of the casing to give it a thicker mounting plate with bigger holes for 3/8 inch bolts. I also modified the dimensions to give only 1/16th of an inch between the magnets and the coil plate. I've also taken the case STL and created a no mounting plate version of the case. You can use either case STL or both, it's up to you, just don't forget the two rubber O-rings. I also modified the coil plate to have terminal bolt holes to attach the 4 wires to (3 phases and 1 ground). 1/23/2015 I've redesigned several parts after attempting prints. The design is now intended to print using PLA with a 100% fill. The magnets get epoxied into place. The coil plate after wiring and placing the coils will get a pour of epoxy resin into the plate up to the top to hold the whole thing in place. It will add rigidity to it and act as a thermal mass to reduce heat into the PLA surrounding it. I'm going to attempt low fill pieces tomorrow to check fit to include fit of the rubber O-rings. Also realized that you will need to create 4 bolts to tie the wires to that will need holes and you will need drainage holes that will need to be drilled based on orientation.

If you get the reference, awesome... if u don't... shame shame shame... Inspired from one of my favorite movies, "Tron"
Like my previous upload, this was meant to glue over the existing umbrella handle. Again I don't have a 3D printer so if someone does print this, let me know that it works and upload a pic plz :D Thank you~!

title: Quarter roll coin holder from Airborne container (spring-loaded)

description.text:
Convert empty Airborne container into a spring-loaded holder for US quarters.
Design is fully parametric in case you have different container or coin size.

This design was tested and works great with off-brand versions of Airborne.
Print from PLA fits perfectly on the bottle. If you need to tune the design, change some variable, they all commented.
It is possible to print only one part by commenting out the other. Besides 2 printed parts and Airborne container you will need a spring. It should be not too strong, roughly 3/4in in diameter and 3-1/4 to 3-1/2in long. Diameter may be up to ~0.9 in, as long as it fits into the piston.
P.S. Spring from the inside of the cheapest plastic toilet paper roll holder from Home Depot ($1.85) works perfectly!!! You may want to decrease piston height variable to match the height of a fully compressed spring. Lastly, after printing you may have to file coin receptacle a little bit to make it smoother.

• This stand is big enough to stably hold a full sized ipad while still fitting on a stock printrbot.
  • Iterative reinforcement (after repeated, absent-minded, destructive fiddling :p) has made this stand pretty indestructible with minimal waste.

I'd recommend using PLA with at least 3 outer shells and 20% infill.

author: jintai

description.text:
Modified version of "Yet Another Cable Chain" by tosjduenfs.
I made the bridges a lot easier to be printed (since my printer had problems printing them). I also made snapping the hinges a bit easier (flattened the raise on one side a bit). On the bottom, I shortened the ends a bit to allow for a little "counter-bending".
It's also a bit longer: about 17mm per piece.
Several end pieces are coming soon. (If I don't forget it ;))

I experienced best results for ABS using .2 mm layer height, 1.8 w/h and with almost no or even no infill but 2 extra shells instead of one, so most of the piece is printed in loops (in skeinforge words). This adds a bit flexibility to make snapping pieces together easier and they will be printed a bit faster than with infill.
The diagonal part below the bridge is to support printing the bridge and can be filed off if you want (I kept them). Should be easier to print on printers having problems with long bridges.

This model is the result of my teaching myself Solidworks over the course of my end of the year vacation.  I took Audrey2's excellent Accurate Dalek model and redrew every part of it from scratch, using it along with photos and some recycled pieces of my older Dalek models.  The goal was to make a reasonably accurate and detailed Dalek model that was also easy to print and assemble and could be made entirely out of printed parts.  
This model is not as accurate as Audrey2's, but at the scale it's designed to print at you won't be able to tell the difference.  It is made up entirely of printed parts (which meant some serious loss of fidelity on the eyestalk and gun, but that's unavoidable) with the exception of a single piece of 1.75mm filament for the eyestalk hinge.  It does need some glue to be assembled, but not much as most of the parts friction-fit together well.

Print one each of the bumper, core, eye, and plunger pieces in black.  
Print two of the armball pieces in black (or silver, the props used on the show are inconsistent).  
Print one each of the skirt, shoulder, dome, and two each of the three ring halves in brown, or your preferred base color.  Note that the shoulder will probably need to be printed with support, and the dome may as well.  
Print two lamps, two eyestalk halves, two gun halves, and one plunger arm in silver.  
Print one shoulder joint cap file in gold.  Note that there are two pieces in this file.  
Print one of the slats file.  Note that this file contains 18 separate pieces in it.  Each one of the slats is different, and each goes in a specific slot on the shoulder piece.  I recommend printing the shoulder piece, then the slats, and then removing each slat from the print bed and attaching them to the shoulder piece one at a time so you don't get them confused.  
Print 54 of the bumps in gold or whatever color you made the slats, and 54 of the bump rings in black or silver or your choice of colors.  
Print 1 dome pin in any color you like.  
The bumps and bump rings attach to the skirt without glue or fasteners.  Put the bumps through the rings, then through the holes in the skirt, and then turn them 90 degrees to lock them in place.  
The skirt should press down onto the bumper and hold in place by friction.  Likewise, the core piece should press into the top of the skirt and hold itself in place.  You may want to add a dab of glue to hold them.  
Each slat presses into a corresponding slot on the shoulder.  They should hold in place by friction, but again a dab of glue is recommended.  
Each arm ball fits into a socket on the front of the shoulder assembly.  The shoulder joint caps go over them and hold them in place.  These need to be glued in place, but the glue has to be applied very carefully so as to not jam the balls in place.  Unless you don't care that the gun and plunger don't move, in which case it's easy to assemble.  
Trim the bits of support from the plunder arm, and then glue it into the back of the plunger and the right side arm ball.  Glue the sides of the gun together and press it into the other arm ball.  
The shoulder assembly slides over the core and should sit flush on top of the skirt.  The two halves of each ring then snap together into the grooves on the core.  Ring 1 is the bottom one, ring 3 is the top.  
The lamps insert through the holes in the bottom of the dome.  They will probably need a little glue to stay in place.  
Glue the two halves of the eyestalk together, and then glue them into the back of the eye piece.  Slide the round bit at the back of the eyestalk through the slot on the front of the dome.  Cut a piece of 1.75mm filament to about half an inch, and then push it through the round hole at the back of the eyestalk piece.  Then push the filament piece and eyestalk back forward so the filament piece fits snugly in the cross slot inside the dome.  
Push the dome pin into the hole in the center underside of the dome, then push it down into the mating hole on the top of the core.  The dome should turn freely.

author: madloxman

title: 6 x 6 Inch Glass Bed Clips for Printrbot Jr.

description.text:
So I stopped by the hardware store last weekend, interested in picking up some glass to experiment with for a print platform (It looks like the laser-cut plywood might be starting to warp, I live in a humid place).  They guys there were nice enough to just cut me a 6" x 6" piece of scrap window glass for free, since I'd have to pay for the whole sheet (24" x 24") otherwise.
After three generations of so-so results (lots of slippage, and they tended to reduce my X-Axis travel by getting in the way), I've settled on this to mount it.  It also uses some of those little Goody brand rubber bands to keep tension, something like $2 at the grocery store, some springs I found at Home Depot (8mm ID / 20mm Uncompressed Length), and some #4 nuts and bolts.
Printing directly on to the glass has had mixed results.  Since I don't have a heater, I've tried both with and without PLA "Juice", bare glass, and on painters tape.
Printing on bare glass makes for beautiful print surface results.  The bottoms come out looking like a mirror.  The problem is the parts don't stick very well.  Tried smooshing the bottom layer, still dislodges whenever there is too much sideways force.
With the PLA Juice (elmers glue + water), it printed okay.  I still had issues with sticking on longer prints.  I heard I'm supposed to use PLAc glue, but I have no idea what that is.  Might try it next time I stop by the hardware store.
I'm currently running with the blue tape, so this gives it a little extra bite around the corners.
In the end, I got a super-flat build platform that is way easier to clean and retape compared to the plywood.  I also don't have to worry about the warping issue I had before, though with the added X-Y tension, it may migrate down the to X Carriage.

4 x #4 Bolts (Similar to ones that came with the Printrbot Jr.)
4 x #4 Nuts (Same thing, similar to the ones that came with it.)
4 x Springs (I got a little baggy of 6 springs from Home Depot, smallest ones I could find, I.D. of 8mm / height of about 20mm).

• Print. I used 10% Infill, 2 Perimeters, with support.

  • Clean off the support structures, file down anything that gets in the way.

  • Assemble them.
    • They are laid out int he STL the same way they fit on my Printrbot Jr. I placed the #4 bolt in the clip first, then the spring on the bottom, the spring holder, then the knob and the bolt underneath. I found that without the spring holder, the bottom of the spring would move around after long prints and throw my level off. I also had to cut off the bottoms of my #4 bolts so they wouldn't get stuck on the screws underneath the X Carriage. Depending on the screws you use, you might have to do the same.
  • Add the rubber bands.
    • They use 4 rubber bands to keep tension on the glass plate, stretched around each of the outer pegs (you can see them in the picture). On my previous builds, they'd start to wander and the glass bed would end up sliding around. Sor far, It's worked pretty well. You might want to stretch them out first, to get them easier to put on.
  • Add glass.
    • I just fit the left side in, then the right, and pressed the front and back sides to get a good hold of the glass.
  • That's it!

comments.text:
I started using Elmers glue stick on unheated glass when printing with PLA. Find the kind that starts purple and drys clear. The problem I have now is getting it off the glass. A little water around the print usually does the trick.
It is 98 cents for two glue sticks at Walmart. I tried a lot of different glues and blue tape and this works the best.

title: Angle Taker - Easy way to take an angle in tight spaces

description.text:
If you've ever need to take an angle in a space that regular tools can't get into this could be your solution.   
This 'Angle Taker' is designed to take angles in confined spaces. It is printed in two parts (one file) that fit together under a small amount of tension. This tension holds the angle when, with the base part placed on a flat surface, the rotating part is aligned with the surface you want to determine the angle of. Will fit in very small spaces and, as it has designed in tension, nothing to tighten to lock the angle.   
Place on a protractor or align a Smart Phone with an angle measuring App to determine the angle taken.   
Very handy little tool. If the tensions 'wears' away to the extent it won't hold an angle any longer just print another one.
On a Replicator 2 this prints well with raft, 3 shells and 35% fill (to make it fairly strong for such a small thing).

comments.text: Fantastic! This will be a great little tool. Thanks!
comments.author: Menneset

author: muzz64

title: Surfski rudder plug for moulding/casting from.

description.text:
240mm deep, volume of 165mm. Skinnier than the carbon fibre think rudders.
Aluminium has a density of 2.7 x that of water so an aluminium rudder of these dimensions will be approx 280grams when submersed. To protect the surface you can wire brush, annodise and dye....google it. The rudder has a tapered shaft entry, 8mm tapering to 4mm diameter over a length of 60mm. There's also an indentation for drilling and tapping a grub screw but it's better to cut some gripping notches into the SS rudder shaft and cast the aluminium around it. Look up sand casting and get hold of silica sand and bentonite clay, make a moulding box of greater inside dimensions than the fin outside dimensions. Alternatively you can make a mould around it and then cast carbon fibre etc with some low viscosity epoxy resin. Try to find a supplier of infusion moulding resins for best wetting out characteristics. You can also scale the rudder in your slicing program to use in a plane for tail, wing or rudder sections. As a wing, it will provide neutral lift so it's best in an acrobatic plane needing to fly well either side up.
Prints best on my printer currently with Cura set to 1mm nozzle diameter, 30mm/s, 20%fill. Finer layers for less sanding work later.

title: Car Cup Holder Divider with Smart Phone Slot

description.text:
If you want to put the cup holders in your car to more efficient use (as you seldom have coffee in your car) this is worth printing. This 'Cup Holder Divider' just sits in a standard size cup holder (made to 64mm to be slightly loose and fit almost any cup holder) to divide it into three compartments. The centre compartments intended to take a Smart Phone (almost all should fit).   
As a suggestion, place a piece of anti-slip rubber padding underneath to hold it in place without any potential for rattling or rotating through vibration.
On a Replicator 2 this prints well with raft, 3 shells and 20% infill..

Updated 3/26/15 This item helps the Da Vinci 3D printer user to calibrate, or level, their print bed. The other items of this nature that I have seen on Thingiverse have been a bit clumsy to use. This version snaps into place quickly and easily and holds the dial gauge firmly thus allowing a fast and accurate measurement of the bed height at almost any point. At the request of a friend, I have included a version with an LED light. Stepper motors generate a significant electrical current when moved by hand, so some prefer to do a manual calibration with the printer turned off. In this case, they can have an LED shining on the dial and another shining on the tip of the probe. The LED(s) and battery simply press into place, no soldering required. However white LEDs typically are rated at 3.2 volts while a typical button cell battery supplies 3.0 volts--therefore you may find the LEDs are a tad dim, especially if you have two installed. (See the Instructions tab.) This is one source for the dial gauge, there are many others. http://www.amazon.com/TEKTON-7169-0-1-Inch-Dial-Indicator/dp/B000NPPBVK (Note 3/26) Updated the LED version to clear the belt. Replaced the file DaVinci_Calibrator_with_LED.stl with DaVinci_Calibrator_LED_V2.stl. I added some Mesh Mixer supports in the battery slot, they should come out very easily. Also. there is not much space between the gauge and the LEDs, I had to trim the legs on the bottom LED by about ¼" (6mm) to line it up properly. (Note 3/24) The file DaVinci_Calibrator.stl was replaced with DaVinci_Calibrator_V2.stl. This version (shown in green in the pictures) has a notch added so as not to rub on the belt when used. I also tightened up the hole for the gauge just a hair. In the next day or two I will add a version with a clip to more securely hold the dial gauge. When all versions are complete I will update the 123D file.

Before use, the printer must be successfully calibrated using the printer's built-in calibration routine at least once. After the printer is satisfied that it has a proper calibration never again start that process. I'll go take a nap while you get the initial calibration part done. To use the calibrator, first start a demo print using the printer's menu. As soon as the print head moves to the table, preferably before the purge line starts to print, turn off the printer. You can at your discretion turn it back on, or leave it off for the remainder of the procedure. However, be aware that the print bed is now hot. Insert your dial gauge (caliper) into the large circular hole on the calibrator. It should be a snug fit, if it is too tight a little light sanding or filing should be all that is needed. Then clip the back of the calibrator onto the rear horizontal rail that the print head rides on. Pull forward gently, you should feel the calibrator snap into place. (See the third picture.) Now rotate it downward until it engages the front rail in a similar fashion. You may now slide the calibrator around in order to measure and adjust the relative height of the entire print bed. If you wish to use the LED version of the calibrator, you will need, in addition to the DaVinci_Calibrator_with_LED model, one or two white 5mm LEDs (size T1¾) and a CR2032 or equivalent battery. Insert the legs of the LED into the small angled holes and press the battery into the slot. Be aware that the LED and battery are both polarized, the longer leg of the LED is positive, as is the larger flat side of the battery. If the LED does not light, check the polarity and/or try reinserting the LED. There is no switch, as soon as the legs of the LED make proper contact with the battery it will turn on, and stay on until one or both are removed.

comments.text: This is the best DaVinci 1.0 Pro calibrator available on Thingiverse.  I made the calibrator with mount using PLA.  I use the calibrator with a Clockwise Tools DIGR-0105 digital indicator gauge (1"/25.4 mm throw) with a four digit readout.  The gauge mount on the calibrator guarantees that the digital indicator gauge does not move out of position during measurements.  I also like the way the calibrator snaps into position on the extruder rails.  I use the digital indicator gauge in a relative measurement (zero the indicator at the center of the bed) across the aluminum print bed to check on the differences in spacing between the printbed and rails as a function of position on the printbed.  I also use it in an absolute measurement to check on the effect of extruder to print bed spacing on thing printbed adhesion and print quality.  This calibrator has saved me a lot of time and effort.

comments.text: Yeah, that issue has been pointed out to me by several people. It's due to intrsecting meshes. comments.author: Blank182

comments.text:
Thanks for commenting :)
I'm a bit unhappy with the tolerances on this one.
The tolerances are so big that when one pulls on the chain with too much force (there really is not much force necessary) the cones wedge apart the successive clamping segment-pair wide enough to break the chain.
On the pro side this means this design is safely usable as a tight necklace.
But I wanted a sturdy chain (maybe for driving 3D printers). So I made a version that replaces the conical protrusions and indents with an additional axle-part-type. The new segments have fully penetrating holes on the side where the segments touch (replacing male protruding cones) and dead end cylindrical holes on the other (replacing female conical indents). With this new design there is no more wedging apart. This new design is already finished but I kept adding too much details. -- Long overdue for publishing!

title: Customizable Straight Beam for LEGO Technic

description.text:
Here's a straight beam that works with LEGO Technic. You can design your own beam with the Customizer - just select the number of holes - or download one of the sample files I've included.  
This model is based on projunk's Parametric LEGO Technic Beam but modified in two ways. The basic parameters were tweaked to better match LEGO parts when printed on a Replicator 2 with PLA. I also added an angle to the countersink on the bottom so they can be printed nicely without support.

Designed in OpenSCAD, sliced in Simplify3D, printed on a MakerBot Replicator2 with Elmer's Craft Bond glue stick on a glass build plate with PushPlastic filament and the following settings: Infill = 20%
Layer height = 0.2
No. shells = 4
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220C No support is needed.

description.text: I printed the shelled one with very sparse support and filled the model with plaster afterwards to make it heavy.
I used 100mm and 120mm smooth rods to hold the "forks"
This is a model of an Epson robotic assembly arm.

NEW VERSION 2!!!
The original spirals had problem with some slicer, so I redone them with more accurate geometry. Spirals useful for leveling and calibrate delta beds (or other) from 40mm to 400mm. The spirals are actually a small square of 0.25mm side that spins in circles.

Set the layer height in your slicer from 0.2mm to 0.5mm for best results. Lower height than 0.2mm will result in 2 layers or more, greater than 0.5mm will result in no layers detected.  
You can combine the spirals on your bed if you need more time (or fun). The spirals will match together in 20mm diameter increment. You can also combine the 40mm with a bigger one, validating the flatness of your plate.

title: Grip Layer for Soft Robot Gripper

description.text: After making hahvahdsquah's Soft Robot Gripper (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66883) and reading Soft Robotics for Chemists (http://gmwgroup.harvard.edu/pubs/pdf/1112.pdf), I was inspired to make an add-on to hahvahdsquah's design by making an additional layer for the gripper the provides more gripping ability.

Follow the Instructable here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Air-Powered-Soft-Robotic-Gripper/?ALLSTEPS. On step 1, print whichever one of my molds matches up with the main gripper mold that you printed. In between step 3 and 4, pour the silicone mix into the mold. Then, SKIP step 4. During step nine, instead apply silicone on the flat side of the product of my molds, and press that to the open side of the gripper itself. Let cure.

author: XYZAidan

description.text:
This simple doodad slips on to the end of an IKEA JANSJÖ lamp to gently dim and diffuse its piercing light, so that you can look directly at it without burning your eyes to smoking craters.  Print with more opaque filament for a greater dimming and diffusing effect.  
This is sized to fit onto the end of the lamp exactly, without need for any adhesive.  However, due to the tolerances involved, try printing the lamp first a bit quick and dirty and check it for fit, and size it up or down by 1% before printing again.

title: Adjustable Spool Holder - 608 Bearing Based - With Adjustment Knobs

description.text:
Yet another spool holder, sure there are other designs out there but I just had to design my own. What sets this one apart? Knobs. No screwdriver required for adjusting the width of the spool. Designed to accommodate the various spool sizes I've encountered so far (Printrbot both 1.1 and 2.2lbs, Seacans, and Filaments.ca). Utilizes easy to find 608 bearing (skateboard bearings) and about $5 worth of metric nuts and bolts. Hardware:
Four 608 Skateboard Bearings
Four 20mm M8 Hex Bolts (May use cap style instead)
Four M8 Hex Nuts
Four 20mm M5 Hex Bolts (Must be hex head NOT cap head)
Four M5 split ring washers Tools:
Hammer for gently encouraging M5 bolts into the printed knobs.
Fingers or needle nose pliers, do not use wrenches as you don't need that much force or you could break your parts. Printer Settings: These are what I used on my Printrbot Simple Metal
0.4mm Layer Height
15% Honeycomb Infill
2 Perimeters
2 Top/Bottom Layers

Assembly animation: http://youtu.be/IV3c_0B5Mo4 Really the only tricky part to assembling this is getting the knobs onto the M5 bolts, this was designed with minimal tolerances, I gently encouraged the bolt into the knob first with a hammer (repeat GENTLY!) I then took the bolt back out and did this about 3 times total for each knob, this ensured I could push the knob down onto the bolt just with my fingers after but a snug enough fit that it wasn't going to pop off. Once you've prepped the knobs align one side piece and one slot bar, put a split washer on 1 M5 bolt, insert an M5 nut into the slot bar, thread bolt into nut and hand tighten. Add the other slot bar and repeat, then add the remaining side piece and install nuts in the same fashion. At this point the M5 bolts should be hand tightened to the point where the slot bar is just a bit tough to adjust the width of the spool holder. Install knobs onto M5 nuts. Install M8 bolts through side panels, place bearings on bolts, hand tighten M8 nuts onto the M8 bolts. All done! I'll post an assembly animation soon too though it's probably not really needed.

Unbolt the old ones and bolt on the new ones. Fastest upgrade ever.

title: Gate of Aqebi Expansion for Khet 1.0

description.text: This is a new expansion for Khet 1.0: The Gate of Aqebi. My original inspiration was to make a game piece that could block and die like an Obelisk or could rotate and "hide" from the laser. However, once I started researching Egyptian gates, I came across the Book of Gates and found some interesting ancient writings about the Gate of Aqebi. (http://www.ancientegyptonline.co.uk/bookgates2.html) As a result I have decided on a slightly different set of rules.

1) The Gate of Aqebi is a replacement for the Obelisks and Anubis game pieces. Simply place them wherever these pieces would normally be during setup.  
2) The Gate of Aqebi can make the same movements as Obelisks and Anubis: one space or rotate 90 degrees.  
3) The Gate of Aqebi cannot be removed from the game. If a laser hits the side of the gate, the laser is blocked for this turn, and the gate must rotate 90 degrees immediately after the laser stops. This does not count as a player's turn (it is an automatic movement).  
4) If the laser passes through the gate, the gate does not rotate automatically. Remove any pieces that are hit by the laser as normal.  
That's it! Short and sweet! I think this has some great potential for really fun game play. If you have any questions or come up with some alternate house rules, please leave a comment.

Print the gate and glue it to the base. Print both upside down and you won't need any support material.  
I printed with 20% fill at 100 mm/s on my Ulitmaker 1.0 in red and silver PLA.

This AppleTV Mount was designed by an 8th Grader to solve a real-world problem. AppleTVs are relatively cheap and offer some amazing features, so we wanted to add these quickly and simply to our AV systems in classrooms. We wanted to mount AppleTVs directly to the projector, and neither velcro or double-sided tape could handle the job.

Default settings work well. This can be printed without support, but some drooping will occur. For best results, print with support. Read more about the design here: http://tech.savvyteachers.com/2012/11/12/stem-in-action-functional-3d-appletv-mount-designed-by-an-8th-grader/

description.text:
This is a mod of the awesome Parametric Servo Arms post by hugokernel.
I have attempted to add support for 2F-size servo hubs (in my case for use with a Turnigy TG9e.)
Also added a Taper option so that long arms don't get too narrow. [Update 13-May-2016: Have now also added support for 15-tooth 1F-size hubs.] By the way, I'm really glad so many people have gotten use of this... But when you parameterize yourself a new one, please un-check the "Publish This" box.

Just enter the arm-length in mm, the number of arms, and now whether this is for a 3F (1/4") 2F (3/16"), or 1F (5/32") hub.  
There is also a setting for the amount of taper for the arms.  
These will typically be very snug on the hub.  A bit of force in seating these onto the servo will set the teeth-marks into the plastic.

remixed_from.author: lorenmcconnell
remixed_from.title: Bezier curves and knots script for Blender

description.text: I am uploading this design in honor of St. Patrick's Day. I saw the "Celtic Crosses" Thing by jpearce (linked), and couldn't resist doing it my own way. This is another product of my Bezier Curves script for Blender. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56629 ) This is a somewhat more complex application than I have attempted so far, and I am pleased with the result. Actually, generating the geometry for the braids was the easy part... What I've struggled with is to "clean" the meshes that Blender produces. The knot meshes are self-intersecting, and Blender tends to produce non-manifold geometry in Bezier curves. After fixing the manifold issues, Blender still fails in boolean operations with the Bezier curve meshes. I have tried to clean the meshes in MeshLab also, but without success. It can select and delete non-manifold faces, but that leaves holes in the mesh, and the automated hole filling tool has not yielded satisfactory results. I found a way to remove hidden faces using ambient occlusion, but that leaves behind the self-intersecting faces where the braids overlap. And I've found no automated way to correct them. Given the size and complexity of these meshes, I need an automated way to address these issues. On the bright side, Makerbot MakerWare did seem to handle the slicing of this dirty mesh -- it reported no errors. Of course, the Proof is in the Printing, and since I failed to win the recent MakerBot Challenge, I am as yet still without a printer. I am posting this as a work in progress, pending a successful cleaning of the mesh. In the meantime, I welcome input on the best known methods for cleaning meshes of internal (hidden, useless) geometry and self-intersecting faces. UPDATE 2013 Mar18: The Netfabb cloud service (http://cloud.netfabb.com/) did very good work with this mesh. It took two passes, though. The first run through Netfabb dropped half of the center knot. So, I took that repaired mesh, added in the second half of that knot and sent it back to Netfabb. The result still has about 40 non-manifold vertices, but that's MUCH better than it was. I uploaded the result.

comments.text: Made one and its really very nice. Thanks

comments.text: have you tried the mesh repair service?

comments.text: Thanks for the tip!  See my update in the description.  Netfabb did help quite a bit.  Not quite perfect, but really good for the price!

This is a toy car that uses a single marble as the wheels. Slides well on smooth surfaces. Remixed from Defauld's "toy car" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:502795) Also included is an stl for just a slider thing, without the car body.

This is made for a 16mm diameter marble, and is about 5.5cm long, and 3.5cm wide. You can scale it up to whatever bigger size, as long as the marble is also scaled up proportionally (if anyone has a huge printer, a bowling-ball sized one would be awesome!). Print with low infill (I used .05%) to keep the marble weight to car weight ratio high.
I used 0.3mm layers. You need to put the marble in partway through the print. When it gets to 17mm height (layer 57 with 0.3 mm layers), pause the print and drop the marble in.

description.text: One more Reuleaux polygons related Thing! These solids called spheroforms have a constant diameter even if they have ridges! Roll them under a book, it will stay horizontal like if it was on 'real' sphere.

description.text:
This is a lens cap for the end of a 1.25 Inch Astronomical eyepiece. This is suitable for all 1.25 Inch eyepieces. Probably best to make it from HDPE as its more flexible. Though I have still to test it! There are also 2 and 0.965 sizes available! Oh, and Ive added in a 1.5mm air release hole.
Not tested yet, so dont know how well the 2mm wall thickness holds up! Will let people know and upload a pic once its done!
Edit:
Ive removed the air release hole, the printed parts are not airtight anyway, and this makes them quicker and less compex to print. Also reduced the wall thickness and removed the fillet from the big-end.

Print, use.
And try not to lose it like you lost the one it came with . . . .

remixed_from.author: CyberCyclist
remixed_from.title: SONY HDR-AZ1VR Attachment for Gopro Mount

title: SONY HDR-AZ1VR Attachment for Gopro Mount v2

description.text:
An attachment for SONY HDR-AZ1VR to use GoPro mount system. Using M4 screw(10mm) to fix AZ1VR. Doesn't block buttons, indicator, connectors, battery cover, mic/speaker. New features in v2:
-Rain cover for USB port (already tested in rain!)
-Lens protection
-Lens cap Glue 4 neodym magnets to fix the rain cover.
I designed two model versions, one for 6mm x 2.4mm mangets(easy to buy in japan), and another for 1/4 x 1/16 inch magnets (popular in US?). But I haven't tested 1/4 inch magnet model. So if it doesn't fit, please fix the model and upload!
And I recommend to coat the rain cover with lacquer. Printer: AFINIA H480
Filament: ABS
Modeler: Autodesk 123D Design
Slicer: UP! V2.13
Settings: Default [Japanese]
SONY HDR-AZ1VRでGoProマウントが利用できるようにするアタッチメントです。長さ10mmのM4ネジで固定します(写真のネジは「スリワリローレットボルト M4×10mm」)。AZ1のボタン、液晶窓、端子、バッテリカバー、マイク/スピーカー穴に干渉しません。 バージョン2で以下を追加しました。
-USBポートの雨カバー(実際にテスト済み)
-レンズ保護の出っ張り
-レンズキャップ 雨カバーの固定のため、ネオジム磁石を接着する必要があります。
百円ショップセリアで購入できる「超強力マグネット ミニ 8P」を使用します。ファイル名に「6mmx2.4mm-magnet」と付いている方を使用して下さい。なお、ダイソーの「超強力マグネット ミニ 8pcs」はサイズが微妙に違うようです。
また、雨カバーにはラッカースプレー等による防水処理を推奨します。(しなくても大丈夫かもしれませんが)

comments.text: Nice design! I am not a big fan of the magnet-ears "sticking out" - but I don't need the rear-cover, so I shall just leave it out :) I think that the Sony HDR-series design has a major design-flaw - the dome of the lens is the farthest point sticking out - hence the first one that will get scratched. I guess your "hood" is intended to protect the lens against dings during use too, right?
comments.author: Rocochet
